newsitem.title: USA: Intel more than doubled fourth-quarter profits.
newsitem.headline: Intel more than doubled fourth-quarter profits.

text.p: Intel Corp. on Tuesday reported that its fourth-quarter profits more than doubled, reflecting strong sales of its popular Pentium microprocessors.

The world's largest semiconductor maker said it earned $1.9 billion, or $2.13 a share, in the last three months of 1996, up from $867 million, or 98 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues rose to $6.4 billion from $4.58 billion.
Wall Street analysts on average had expected the company to report fourth-quarter earnings equal to $1.84 per share, according to First Call, which tracks analysts' estimates.

The Santa Clara, Calif.-based semiconductor giant said it earned $5.2 billion, or $5.81 per share, in all of 1996, compared with earnings of $3.6 billion, or $4.03 a share, in 1995. Intel generated $20.8 billion in revenues last year vs. $16.2 billion in 1995.

Intel, which issued its earnings report after markets closed, was the most actively traded stock on Nasdaq, with more than 14 million shares changing hands. It ended up 25 cents at $147.125, a 52-week high, and the company announced a two-for-one stock split along with its results.
The company, which provides the microprocessors used in 80 percent of the world's computers, is widely regarded as a bellwether for the personal computer group.
